sen.j: 神楽（かぐら）は、神道の神事において神 (神道)に奉納するために奏される歌舞。
sen.e: Kagura is a chanting and dancing performance dedicated to gods in Shinto rituals.
Kagura is a chanting and dancing performance dedicated to gods in Shinto rituals.
Kagura is a chanting and dancing performance dedicated to gods in Shinto rituals.

sen.j: 神社の祭などで見ることができ、まれに寺院で行うところもある。
sen.e: Kagura may be observed at shrine festivals, and rarely at some temples.
Kagura may be observed at shrine festivals, and rarely at some temples.
Kagura may be observed at shrine festivals, and rarely at some temples.

sen.j: 「かぐら」の語源は、「神座」（かむくら・かみくら）が転じたものとする説が一般的である。
sen.e: The word "Kagura" is commonly believed to have been transferred from "kamukura/kamikura (a seat for gods.)"
The word "Kagura" is commonly believed to have been transferred from "kamukura/kamikura" (a seat for gods).
The word 'kagura' is commonly believed to have been transferred from 'kamukura' (a seat for gods).
sen.cmt: 読みを「かむくら」に統一し、クォーテーションを変えました。

sen.j: 神座とは「神の宿るところ」を意味し、神座に神々を降ろし、巫女が集まった人々の汚れを祓ったり、神懸かりとなって神の意志を伝えたり、また人の側からは願望が伝えられるなど、神人一体の宴を催す場であり、そこでの歌舞が神楽と呼ばれるようになったと考えられている。
sen.e: "Kamukura/kamikura" means "a place for gods to stay" where Shinto gods shall descend and enjoy together with the people a feast of chanting and dancing, which became called Kagura, while miko (shrine maidens) purify uncleaness of gathered people and become mediumistic to transfer the gods' will to the people and the people's wish to the gods.

"Kamukura/kamikura" means "a place for gods to stay" where Shinto gods shall descend and enjoy together with the people a feast of chanting and dancing, which became called Kagura, while miko (shrine maidens) purify uncleaness of gathered people and become mediumistic to transfer the gods' will to the people and the people's wish to the gods.

Kamukura means 'a place for gods to stay' where Shinto gods shall descend and enjoy together with the people a feast of chanting and dancing, which became called kagura, while miko (shrine maidens) purify uncleanness of gathered people and become mediumistic to transfer the gods' will to the people and the people's wish to the gods.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に統一、クォーテーションを変えました。

sen.j: 古事記および日本書紀においては、天岩戸の段でアメノウズメが神懸りして舞ったという日本神話が神楽の起源であるとされる。
sen.e: According to Kojiki (the Record of Ancient Matters) and Nihonshoki (the Chronicle of Japan), Kagura had its origin in a Japanese ancient myth of the oracular Ameno Uzume (goddess of the dawn and revelry) who had performed a dance in front of Amano Iwato (literally, rock door of the heaven.)

According to the Kojiki (the Record of Ancient Matters) and Nihonshoki (the Chronicle of Japan), Kagura had its origin in a Japanese ancient myth of the oracular Ameno Uzume (goddess of the dawn and revelry) who had performed a dance in front of Amano Iwato (literally, rock door of the heaven).

According to Kojiki (the Record of Ancient Matters) and Nihonshoki (the Chronicle of Japan), kagura had its origin in a Japanese ancient myth of the oracular Amenouzume (goddess of the dawn and revelry) who had performed a dance in a chapter of Ama no iwato (Cave of heaven).

sen.j: アメノウズメの子孫とされる猿女君は宮中において鎮魂の儀に携わっており、このことから神楽の元々の形は鎮魂・魂振に伴う神遊びであったとも考えられる。
sen.e: Since Sarumenokimi, who is regarded as a descendant of Ameno Uzume, was engaged in rituals for repose of souls, original form of Kagura may be considered to have been an entertainment of the gods accompanying formal rituals for repose and shaking of souls.

Since Sarumenokimi, who is regarded as a descendant of Ameno Uzume, was engaged in rituals for the repose of souls, the original form of Kagura may be considered to have been an entertainment of the gods accompanying formal rituals for repose and the shaking of souls.

Since Sarumenokimi, who was regarded as a descendant of Amenouzume, was engaged in rituals for the repose of souls, the original form of kagura may be considered to have been an entertainment of the gods accompanying formal rituals for repose and the shaking of souls.
sen.cmt: 過去形にし、表記を変えました。

sen.j: 神楽は、宮中で行われる御神楽（みかぐら）と、民間で行われる里神楽（さとかぐら）に分けられる。
sen.e: Kagura can be classified into two kinds, Mikagura and Satokagura, the former being performed in the imperial court and the latter among ordinary people.
Kagura can be classified into two kinds, Mikagura and Satokagura, the former being performed in the imperial court and the latter among ordinary people.
Kagura can be classified into two kinds, mikagura and satokagura, the former being performed in the imperial court and the latter among ordinary people.

sen.j: 里神楽は民俗芸能研究の第一人者である本田安次(1906-2001)がさらに大きく巫女神楽・出雲流神楽・伊勢流神楽・獅子神楽に分類した。
sen.e: Yasuji HONDA (1906-2001), a foremost authority of folklore entertainment, has further divided the Satokagura into Miko-kagura (Kagura performed by shrine maidens,) Izumoryu-kagura (Izumo style Kagura,) Iseryu-kagura (Ise style Kagura) and Shishi-kagura (lion style Kagura.)

Yasuji HONDA (1906-2001), a foremost authority of folklore entertainment, has further divided the Satokagura into Miko-kagura (Kagura performed by shrine maidens,) Izumoryu-kagura (Izumo style Kagura,) Iseryu-kagura (Ise style Kagura) and Shishi-kagura (lion style Kagura.)

Yasuji HONDA (1906 - 2001), a foremost authority of folklore entertainment, has further divided the satokagura into miko-kagura (kagura performed by shrine maidens), Izumoryu-kagura (Izumo school of kagura), Iseryu-kagura (kagura of Ise school) and shishi-kagura (lion style Kagura).

sen.j: これらの流れを汲んだ神楽が各地に存在する。
sen.e: Their descendant Kagura can also be seen everywhere in Japan.
Their descendant Kagura can also be seen everywhere in Japan.
Their descendant kagura can also be seen everywhere in Japan.

sen.j: しかし、この分類では不都合なことも生じてきており、近年里神楽の分類方法の見直しも考えられている。
sen.e: Recently, however, the above way of sorting has became occasionally inconvenient and its review is now under consideration.
Recently, however, the above way of sorting has became occasionally inconvenient and its review is now under consideration.
Recently, however, the above way of sorting has became occasionally inconvenient and its review is now under consideration.

sen.j: 近代に作られた神楽もあり、その中には多くの神社で行われているものもある。
sen.e: There are also some Kagura created in the modern age and performed currently in many shrines.
There are also some Kagura created in the modern age and performed currently in many shrines.
There are also some kagura created in the modern age and performed currently in many shrines.

sen.j: 宮中の賢所で行われる御神楽（賢所御神楽）のことで、古くは内侍所御神楽と言われた。
sen.e: Mikagura, also called Kashikodokoro Kagura, is a formal dancing ritual performed at Kashikodokoro (a palace sanctuary) within the imperial court, which was originally named as Naishidokoro Kagura in ancient time.

Mikagura, also called Kashikodokoro Kagura, is a formal dancing ritual performed at Kashikodokoro (a palace sanctuary) within the imperial court, which was originally named as Naishidokoro Kagura in ancient time.

Mikagura, also known kashikodokoro kagura, is a formal dancing ritual performed at kashikodokoro (a palace sanctuary) within the imperial court, which was originally named as naishidokoro mikagura in ancient time.

sen.j: 雅楽（国風歌舞）に含まれる。
sen.e: Mikagura is included in the category of gagaku or kokufu-kabu (traditional court music and dance.)
Mikagura is included in the category of gagaku or kokufu-kabu (traditional court music and dance).
It is included in the category of gagaku (ancient Japanese court dance and music) (also known as kokufu-kabu (traditional court music and dance)).

sen.j: 大嘗祭の清暑堂での琴歌神宴（神楽）、賀茂神社臨時祭の還立の神楽、園并韓神祭の神楽、石清水八幡宮臨時祭の神楽から成立したと考えられている。
sen.e: It is believed that Mikagura were officially established at such events, firstly as the Kinka-shin-en (viz. Kagura) performed at Seisho-do hall in the imperial court for Daijosai or Onieno-matsuri ceremony (the first ceremonial offering of rice by newly enthroned emperor,) and, secondly, as a Kagura dance performed as Kaeridachi (entertainment of chanting and dancing in front of emperor after an official ritual offered to gods) for the special festival of Kamo shrine, and, thirdly, as a Kagura dance performed for the Sononarabini-karakamino-matsuri festival, and, lastly, as a Kagura dance performed for the Iwashimizu Hachimangu shrine special festival.

It is believed that Mikagura were officially established at such events, firstly as the Kinka-shin-en (viz. Kagura) performed at Seisho-do hall in the imperial court for Daijosai or Onieno-matsuri ceremony (the first ceremonial offering of rice by newly enthroned emperor) and, secondly, as a Kagura dance performed as Kaeridachi (entertainment of chanting and dancing in front of emperor after an official ritual offered to gods) for the special festival of Kamo shrine, and, thirdly, as a Kagura dance performed for the Sononarabini-karakamino-matsuri festival, and, lastly, as a Kagura dance performed for the Iwashimizu Hachimangu shrine special festival.

It is believed that mikagura were officially established at such events, firstly as the Kinka-shinen (kagura) performed at Seisho-do hall in the imperial court for Daijosai (the first ceremonial offering of rice by newly enthroned emperor) and, secondly, as a kagura dance performed as Kaeridachi (entertainment of chanting and dancing in front of emperor after an official ritual offered to gods) for the special festival of Kamo-jinja Shrine, and, thirdly, as a kagura dance performed for the Sono narabi Kara kami no matsuri (festival for both the southern shrine for Sonokami (god) and the northern shrine for Karakami (god) enshrined in Kunaisho (Ministry of the Sovereign's Household)), and, lastly, as a kagura dance performed for the Iwashimizu Hachimangu Shrine special festival.

sen.j: 長保4年（1002年）あるいは寛弘2年（1005年）から隔年で行われるようになり、後に毎年の行事となった。
sen.e: Those Mikagura had been performed every two years since 1002 or 1005 until they were changed to be held every year.
Such Mikagura had been performed every two years since 1002 or 1005 until they were changed to be held annually.
Such mikagura had been performed every two years since 1002 or 1005 until they were changed to be held annually.

sen.j: 簡略化されてはいるが宮内庁式部職楽部によって、現在も毎年12月中旬に賢所で行われ、大嘗祭でも行われる。
sen.e: Although simplified, Mikagura is currently performed at Kashikodokoro (a palace sanctuary) in the middle of December every year by the Music Department of the Board of Ceremonies, Imperial Household Agency, as well as for Onieno-matsuri (first ceremonial offering of rice by newly-enthroned Emperor.)
sen.cmt: Ceremonial Office [定訳未詳]→Music Department of Board of Ceremonies, Imperial Household Agency [定訳未詳]
sen.e: Although simplified, Mikagura is currently performed at Kashikodokoro (a palace sanctuary) in the middle of December every year by the Music Department of the Board of Ceremonies, Imperial Household Agency, as well as for the Onieno-matsuri (first ceremonial offering of rice by newly-enthroned Emperor.)

Although simplified, mikagura is currently performed at Kashikodokoro in the middle of December every year by Shikibushoku Gakubu (Music Department) of Imperial Household Agency as well as for the Daijosai.
sen.cmt: 前出用語に合わせました。

sen.j: 一般に神楽と言われているもの。
sen.e: Generally, Satokagura is called just "Kagura."
Generally, Satokagura is called just "Kagura."
Generally, it is what people called kagura.

sen.j: 里神楽という語は御神楽との対比に用いられ、狭義では関東での民間の神楽に用いられる。
sen.e: The word "Satokagura" is used in comparison with Mikagura, while, in a more limited sense, it means private Kagura performed in Kanto area.
The word "Satokagura" is used in comparison with Mikagura, while, in a more limited sense, it means private Kagura performed in Kanto area.
The word satokagura is used in comparison with mikagura, while, in a more limited sense, it means private kagura performed in Kanto region.
sen.cmt: クォーテーションをのぞき、表記などを変えました。

sen.j: 巫女神楽
sen.e: Miko-kagura
Miko-kagura
Miko-kagura

sen.j: 巫女が舞う神楽。
sen.e: Miko-kagura means a Kagura dance to be performed by miko (shrine maidens.)
Miko-kagura means a Kagura dance to be performed by miko (shrine maidens.)
Miko-kagura means a kagura dance performed by miko.

sen.j: 神がかりのために行われた舞がもととなり、それが様式化して祈祷や奉納の舞となった。
sen.e: Originally it was performed in order for miko to feel mediumistic, but later it became formalized to be an official dance for prayers and devotions to gods.
Originally it was performed in order for miko to feel mediumistic, but later it became formalized as an official dance for prayers and devotion to gods.
Originally it was performed for possession by the supernatural, and later it became formalized as a dance for prayers and devotion to gods.

sen.j: 前者の特徴は順・逆に回って舞うことなどで、その古態を残すところもあるが、現在では後者がほとんどである。
sen.e: The former case was featured by dances whirling in order and reverse order, and this old manner of dancing is still seen somewhere in Japan, although the latter case is now dominant.
The former case was featured by dances whirling in order and reverse order, and this old manner of dancing is still seen somewhere in Japan, although the latter case is now dominant.
The former case was featured by dances whirling in order and reverse order, and this old manner of dancing is still seen in some performance, although the latter case is now dominant.

sen.j: 鈴・扇子・ササ・サカキ・御幣など依り代となる採物を持って舞う。
sen.e: A miko (a shrine maiden) dancer dances with a bell, a folding fan, a dwarf bamboo, a twig of sakaki tree (a sacred tree of Shinto), gohei (a wooden wand decorated with two zigzag paper streamers) and other torimono (objects in hands of a Kagura dancer) which are regarded as yorishiro (substances on which gods are invited to descend.)

A miko (a shrine maiden) dancer dances with a bell, a folding fan, a dwarf bamboo, a twig of sakaki tree (a sacred tree of Shinto), gohei (a wooden wand decorated with two zigzag paper streamers) and other torimono (objects in hands of a Kagura dancer) which are regarded as yorishiro (substances on which gods are invited to descend.)

They perform with torimono (symbolic offerings) in their hands, such as a bell, a folding fan, a dwarf bamboo, a twig of sakaki tree (a sacred tree of Shinto), and gohei (a wooden wand decorated with two zigzag paper streamers), as yorishiro (object representative of a divine spirit).

sen.j: 出雲流神楽
sen.e: Izumoryu-kagura (Izumo style Kagura)
Izumoryu-kagura (Izumo style Kagura)
Izumoryu-kagura
sen.cmt: 前出補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 佐太神社の御座替神事を源流とする神楽。
sen.e: Izumoryu-kagura (Izumo style Kagura) originates from Gozagae Shinji (a Shinto ritual to renew mats for gods to sit on) performed at Sata jinja shrine.
Izumoryu-kagura (Izumo style Kagura) originates from Gozagae Shinji (a Shinto ritual to renew mats for gods to sit on) performed at Sata jinja shrine.
Izumoryu-kagura originates from Gozagae Shinji (Shinto ritual of God place change) performed at Sata-jinja Shrine.

sen.j: この神事（佐陀神能）は取り替えた御座を清めるための採物舞と日本神話や神社縁起を劇化した神能などから成り、この流れを汲んだうえで演劇性を高めた神楽が中国地方中心に全国へ広がっている。
sen.e: This Gozagae Shinji, which is also called Sata Shinnoh (a kind of Noh plays dedicated to Sata jinja shrine,) is composed of two parts, one being a Kagura dance called torimono-mai performed by a miko dancer with substances in hands to purify newly placed mats for gods, and another part being Shinnoh or Noh plays dedicated to gods which were converted into from various Japanese myths and legends of shrines, while in this line of Shinnoh of Gozagae Shinji, Kagura has become more dramatic and spread not only in Chugoku region but across the country.

This Gozagae Shinji, which is also called Sata Shinnoh (a kind of Noh plays dedicated to Sata jinja shrine,) is composed of two parts, one being a Kagura dance called torimono-mai performed by a miko dancer with substances in hands to purify newly placed mats for gods, and another part being Shinnoh or Noh plays dedicated to gods which were converted from various Japanese myths and legends of shrines, while in this line of Shinnoh of Gozagae Shinji, Kagura has become more dramatic and spread not only in Chugoku region but across the country.

This Gozagae Shinji (also known as Sata Shinnoh (a kind of Noh plays dedicated to Sata-jinja Shrine)), is composed by such as torimono-mai dance to purify newly placed mats for gods, and Shinnoh adopting various Japanese myths and legends of shrines, and in this school, the kagura has become more dramatic and spread all over the country, especially in Chugoku region.

sen.j: 特に島根県西部や広島県北西部に伝わる石見神楽の系流は、子供にも人気のある娯楽芸能として確立されている。
sen.e: Especially in the west part of Shimane Prefecture and the northwest of Hiroshima Prefecture, a lineage of traditional Iwami-kagura has now established its popularity among the people including children as an amusement art.

Especially in the west part of Shimane Prefecture and the northwest of Hiroshima Prefecture, a lineage of traditional Iwami-kagura has now established its popularity among the people including children as an amusement art.

Especially, a school of Iwami-kagura in the west part of Shimane Prefecture and the northwest of Hiroshima Prefecture has now established as an amusement art which is popular among people including children.

sen.j: 伊勢流神楽
sen.e: Iseryu-kagura (Ise style Kagura)
Iseryu-kagura (Ise style Kagura)
Iseryu-kagura
sen.cmt: 前出補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 湯立と神楽が結びついたもの。
sen.e: Iseryu-kagura (Ise style Kagura) is a combined form of Kagura and Yutate (a ceremony to boil fresh pure water in front of gods.)
Iseryu-kagura (Ise style Kagura) is a combined form of Kagura and Yutate (a ceremony to boil fresh pure water in front of gods.)
Iseryu-kagura is a combined form of kagura and yudate.
sen.cmt: 湯立は、後に説明があるため、補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 伊勢神宮の摂末社の神楽役たちが行った物が広まったと考えられている。
sen.e: This Kagura is considered to have been spread widely by players of Kagura performed at subsidiary shrines of Ise-jingu shrine.
This Kagura is considered to have been spread widely by players of Kagura performed at subsidiary shrines of Ise-jingu shrine.
This kagura is considered to have been spread widely by players of kagura performed at subsidiary shrines of Ise-jingu Shrine.

sen.j: 霜月神楽、花祭りとも言われる。
sen.e: It is also called Shimotsuki-kagura (Kagura played in November) or Hanamatsuri (flower festival.)
It is also called Shimotsuki-kagura (Kagura played in November) or Hanamatsuri (flower festival.)
It is also known as Shimotsuki-kagura (kagura played in November) or Hanamatsuri (flower festival).

sen.j: 釜を据えて湯を沸かし、巫女などが自ら、あるいは周囲の人にその湯を降りかけて清める湯立に、採物あるいは着面の神楽が加わる。
sen.e: A ceremony of Yutate (water boiling) is performed by miko (a shrine maiden) who boils water in a caldron and sprinkles the hot water on herself or on the people around her to purify them, and this Yutate ceremony is joined by a Kagura dance being played either by a miko dancer with handful torimono substances for purification or by a masked Noh player.

A ceremony of Yutate (water boiling) is performed by miko (a shrine maiden) who boils water in a caldron and sprinkles the hot water on herself or on the people around her to purify them, and this Yutate ceremony is joined by a Kagura dance being played either by a miko dancer with handful torimono substances for purification or by a masked Noh player.

Yudate, a rite that miko and others boil water in a caldron and splash the hot water on themselves or people around to purify them, is joined by kagura dance played either by a miko with torimono or by a masked Noh player.

sen.j: 獅子神楽
sen.e: Shishi-kagura (lion style Kagura)
Shishi-kagura (lion style Kagura)
Shishi-kagura
sen.cmt: 前出補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 獅子舞の一種。
sen.e: Shishi-kagura (lion style Kagura) is a kind of shishimai (lion dances.)
Shishi-kagura (lion style Kagura) is a kind of shishimai (lion dances.)
Shishi-kagura is a kind of shishimai (lion dances).
sen.cmt: 前出補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 風流系とは異なり、獅子頭を神体として各地を巡って祈祷やお払いを行う。
sen.e: Different from Furyu-kei shishimai (a lineage of lion dances belonging to Furyu sect), this Shishi-kagura is played by a dancer bearing a mask of lion head, which is regarded as a sacred part of god's body, to implement prayers and rituals at various local shrines where a band of Kagura players go on a tour.
sen.cmt: 風流系→風流系獅子舞→a lion dance belonging to Furyu sect
sen.e: Different from Furyu-kei shishimai (a lineage of lion dances belonging to Furyu sect), this Shishi-kagura is played by a dancer bearing a mask of lion head, which is regarded as a sacred part of god's body, to implement prayers and rituals at various local shrines where a band of Kagura players go on a tour.

Different from Furyu School of shishimai, this shishi-kagura is played by a dancer bearing a mask of lion head, which is regarded as goshintai (an object of worship housed in a Shinto shrine and believed to contain the spirit of god), to implement prayers and rituals at various local shrines where a band of kagura players go on a tour.

sen.j: 二系統あり、東北地方の山伏神楽と、伊勢国などの太神楽がある。
sen.e: There are two lineages in this Shishi-kagura sect, one is called Yamabushi-kagura (Kagura played by ascetic monks living in mountains) which is performed in Tohoku region, and another one is called Dai-kagura which is performed in Ise and other provinces.

There are two lineages in this Shishi-kagura sect, one is called Yamabushi-kagura (Kagura played by ascetic monks living in mountains) which is performed in Tohoku region, and another one is called Dai-kagura which is performed in Ise and other provinces.

It has two schools; one is called yamabushi-kagura (kagura played by ascetic monks living in mountains) which is performed in Tohoku region, and another called dai-kagura which is performed in Ise and other provinces.

sen.j: 上記は大まかな分類であり、また、各地の神楽にはこれらの幾つかの要素が入り混じっている場合がある。
sen.e: The above mentioned classification is very rough, and, in addition, there are some local Kagura which possibly contain a number of mixed features or elements of the various Kagura.
The above mentioned classification is very rough, and, in addition, there are some local Kagura which possibly contain a number of mixed features or elements of the various Kagura.
The classification mentioned above is very rough, and, in addition, there are some local kagura which possibly contain a number of mixed features of the various kagura.

sen.j: 太神楽
sen.e: Dai-kagura
Dai-kagura
Dai-kagura

sen.j: 伊勢神宮や熱田神宮の神人が各地を巡って（回檀）、神札を配り、竃祓いや村の辻での悪魔祓いとして行った神楽。
sen.e: Dai-kagura is a kind of Kagura performed by godmen of Jingu shrine and Atsuta jingu shrine, who are traveling around the country to visit various local shrines, such travelling activity being called "kaidan (literally, circuit ritual services)", to offer various services such as ofuda kubari (distribution of talismans), kamado-harai (purification of cooking ovens) and akuma-barai (expulsion of devils) to be performed on a road of village.

Dai-kagura is a kind of Kagura performed by godmen of Jingu shrine and Atsuta jingu shrine, who are traveling around the country to visit various local shrines, such travelling activity being called "kaidan (literally, circuit ritual services)," to offer various services such as ofuda kubari (distribution of talismans), kamado-harai (purification of cooking ovens) and akuma-barai (expulsion of devils) to be performed on a road of a village.

Dai-kagura is a kind of kagura performed by jinin (associates of Shinto shrines) of Ise-jingu Shrine and Atsuta-jingu Shrine, who travel around the country to visit various local shrines (kaidan (literally, circuit ritual services)) and distribute talismans, as kamado-harai (purification of cooking ovens) and akuma-barai (expulsion of devils) to be performed on the street of a village.
sen.cmt: ウェブをもとに原文、訳文を変えました。

sen.j: 大神楽・代神楽とも。
sen.e: Dai-kagura can also be written in Japanese letters as大神楽 or 代神楽.
Dai-kagura can also be written in Japanese letters as大神楽 or 代神楽.
Dai-kagura (太神楽) can also be written in Japanese letters as 大神楽 or 代神楽.
sen.cmt: 漢字、スペースを補足しました。

sen.j: 獅子舞と曲芸から成る。
sen.e: It is composed of shishimai (lion dances) and kyokugei (acrobatics.)
It is composed of shishimai (lion dances) and kyokugei (acrobatics).
It is composed of shishimai and kyokugei (acrobatics).
sen.cmt: 前出補足をのぞきました。

sen.j: 伊勢太神楽の獅子舞は回檀先の多くの村々に移入され、それらは伊勢太神楽系の獅子舞と呼ばれる。
sen.e: Shishimai for Ise Dai-kagura (lion dances for Dai-kagura plays dedicated to Ise shrine) were performed at various local shrines as a part of kaidan (circuit rituals), and they were imported to many villages where kaidan were held, so that they are now commonly referred to as shishimai for Dai-kagura dedicated to Ise jingu shrine.

Shishimai for Ise Dai-kagura (lion dances for Dai-kagura plays dedicated to Ise shrine) were performed at various local shrines as a part of kaidan (circuit rituals), and they were imported to many villages where kaidan were held, so that they are now commonly referred to as shishimai for Dai-kagura dedicated to Ise jingu shrine.

Shishimai for Ise dai-kagura (lion dances for dai-kagura plays dedicated to Ise-jingu Shrine) were transmitted at various local villages of kaidan, and they are now known as shishimai of Ise dai-kagura.

sen.j: 熱田派は江戸開府の際に本拠地を江戸に移した。
sen.e: Atsuta group (godmen of Atsuta jingu shrine) shifted their headquarters to Edo (current Tokyo) at the start of Edo bakufu (feudal government of Edo.)
Atsuta group (godmen of Atsuta jingu shrine) shifted their headquarters to Edo (current Tokyo) at the start of Edo bakufu (feudal government of Edo.)
Atsuta school (jinin of Atsuta-jingu Shrine) shifted their headquarters to Edo at the start of the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun).

sen.j: 余興として行われていた曲芸は舞台芸としての太神楽に発展、江戸太神楽や水戸大神楽となった。
sen.e: Kyokugei (acrobatics) played as an entertainment have developed to become a part of Dai-kagura played on stage, namely Edo Dai-kagura and Mito Dai-kagura.
Kyokugei (acrobatics) played as a form of entertainment have developed to become a part of Dai-kagura played on stage, namely Edo Dai-kagura and Mito Dai-kagura.
Kyokugei played as a form of entertainment have developed to become a part of dai-kagura played on stage, namely Edo dai-kagura and Mito dai-kagura.

sen.j: 芸能としての神楽
sen.e: Kagura as an Art of Public Entertainment
Kagura as Art for Public Entertainment
Kagura as Art for Public Entertainment

sen.j: 江戸末期から寄席の登場で祭事色の神楽から演芸の曲芸（所謂ジャグリング）が演じられることが多くなった。
sen.e: Since the emergence of yose (vaudevilles) in a late stage of Edo period, performances in a range from ritualized Kagura to entertainment kyokugei (so called juggling) have become to be often played on stage.

Since the emergence of yose (vaudevilles) in a late stage of the Edo period, performances in a range from ritualized Kagura to entertainment kyokugei (so called juggling) have come to be often played on stage.
Since the emergence of yose (vaudevilles) in a late Edo period, performances in a range from ritualized kagura to entertainment kyokugei (so called juggling) have come to be often played on stage.

sen.j: 寄席では落語、講談とは違い色物と扱われることが多く太神楽曲芸と言う。
sen.e: In the world of yose (vaudevilles), Kagura is often referred to as iromono (the colored) and called Dai-kagura kyokugei (acrobatics of Dai-kagura), apart from rakugo (comic storytellings) and kodan (historical narratives.)

In the world of yose (vaudevilles), Kagura is often referred to as iromono (the colored) and called Dai-kagura kyokugei (acrobatics of Dai-kagura), apart from rakugo (comic storytellings) and kodan (historical narratives.)

In the world of yose, kagura is often referred to as iromono (various entertainments in storytellers' theater other than story telling) and called dai-kagura kyokugei (acrobatics of Dai-kagura), apart from rakugo (comic storytellings) and kodan (historical narratives).

sen.j: 主な演目
sen.e: Major Programs
Major Programs
Major Programs

sen.j: 『曲撥』
sen.e: "Kyokubachi (an acrobatic performance using a number of drumsticks)"
"Kyokubachi" (an acrobatic performance using a number of drumsticks)
"Kyokubachi" (an acrobatic performance using a number of drumsticks)

sen.j: 『長撥の曲』
sen.e: "Nagabachi no kyoku (an acrobatic performance using two normal and one long sticks)"

"Nagabachi no kyoku" (an acrobatic performance using two normal and one long stick)

"Hagoita Aioi no kyoku" (an acrobatic performance using two hagoita battledores and one temari ball)
"Hagoita Aioi no kyoku" (an acrobatic performance using two hagoita battledores and one temari ball)

"Magemari" (an acrobatic performance using a number of temari balls)
"Magemari" (an acrobatic performance using a number of temari balls)

sen.e: "Gokai-jawan (an acrobatic performance using a long rod to support numbers of rolling rice bowls and other items well balanced on top of the rod)"
